title: Going Under
descriptions:
Going Under (2004) is a darkly comic, low-key character study about two damaged people who meet in an underground BDSM dungeon and try, awkwardly and tenderly, to build a relationship beyond their scripted scenes. Peter is a middle-aged, recently divorced psychotherapist adrift in his own life, haunted by the sense that he can listen to everyone but himself. Suzanne is a professional dominatrix who runs sessions in a dim, ritualized basement space, maintaining an exacting control that protects her from the mess of ordinary intimacy. Their first encounters are strictly transactional: negotiated limits, safe words, and carefully choreographed pain that gives Peter a place to surrender and gives Suzanne a role in which she feels powerful and untouchable.

But Peter, trained to look beneath surfaces, becomes fascinated with Suzanne as a person rather than a persona. He starts to request sessions that are less about elaborate scenes and more about talking, asking her about her life and revealing pieces of his own. Suzanne resists at first, wary of the boundary crossing and the risks of being seen. The film tracks their tentative steps: Peter’s fumbling attempts to bring emotional honesty into a context designed to bracket it out, and Suzanne’s oscillation between letting him in and reasserting distance. Between sessions we see Peter’s drab apartment, his strained interactions with his ex, his uncertain footing with patients; Suzanne’s small, carefully curated moments alone; and both of them confronting how much of their identities are roles they perform for others.

As they inch toward a relationship outside the dungeon, the power dynamics invert and blur. Without the scripts and gear, Suzanne feels exposed, while Peter, who sought submission as relief, discovers he craves connection that doesn’t fit neatly into control and surrender. They try mundane dates that feel awkward after the intensity of their scenes. Miscommunications accumulate. Peter’s therapist instincts turn into prying; he keeps looking for a breakthrough, asking Suzanne to explain what drew her to domination and what she’s running from. Suzanne, used to setting limits with clients, sets emotional limits with Peter—and when he pushes, she retreats.

The film avoids titillation in favor of psychological nuance. Scenes in the dungeon are quiet and methodical, often focused on negotiation and aftercare, then juxtaposed with the pair’s clumsy attempts at small talk in diners and on city sidewalks. We learn fragments of their pasts: Peter’s marriage curdled in quiet resentments; Suzanne navigated an industry that rewards an illusion of invulnerability. Neither gets a grand reveal that explains everything; instead, their histories show how pain and control became languages they both understand.

A turning point arrives when Peter asks Suzanne to meet him without the pretense of a session and admits he wants more than the ritual can offer. He speaks not as a client but as a man aching for reciprocity. Suzanne, recognizing the sincerity but fearing dependency and the collapse of her professional boundaries, agrees to try, then finds herself overwhelmed by the unstructured vulnerability. Their next dungeon scene devolves, not in danger but in confusion: the safe word halts not pain but emotion, both of them startled by how close they’ve come to the raw center they’ve been circling.

Secondary characters—Peter’s colleagues and patients, Suzanne’s coworkers and a wary friend—mirror the central couple’s conflict between comfort in roles and the terror of real contact. The city itself feels subterranean even above ground: subway platforms, basements, late-night streets. Throughout, the film asks whether intimacy can grow from a foundation built on rules meant to contain it, and whether two people can translate a relationship from one language to another without losing what drew them together.

In the end, after a painful rupture and a period of silence, Peter and Suzanne meet once more, stripped of costumes and scripts. They acknowledge what they gave each other: a space to be seen, a structure that allowed feeling to surface, and the limits they could not cross without harming themselves. The film closes not with tidy reconciliation but with a quiet acceptance. They part with a complicated tenderness, having gone under—into roles, into memory, into themselves—and resurfaced with a clearer, if lonelier, honesty.
